metadata.title: W3Schools.com
metadata.Keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website
metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, PHP, Python, Bootstrap, Java and XML.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: In the previous chapter, we wrote to a file using w and a modes inside the fopen() function.
content.html: In the previous chapter, we wrote to a file using w and a modes inside the fopen() function.

content.text: To read from a file, you can use the r mode:
content.html: To read from a file, you can use the r mode:

syntaxHighlighting.text: FILE *fptr;// Open a file in read modefptr = fopen("filename.txt", "r");
// Open a file in read mode

content.code: FILE *fptr;// Open a file in read modefptr = fopen("filename.txt", "r");

syntax_highlighting.text: FILE *fptr;// Open a file in read modefptr = fopen("filename.txt", "r");
// Open a file in read mode

content.code_html:
FILE *fptr;

// Open a file in read mode
fptr = fopen("filename.txt", "r");

syntax_highlighting_data.text: FILE *fptr;// Open a file in read modefptr = fopen("filename.txt", "r");
// Open a file in read mode

content.text: This will make the filename.txt opened for reading.
content.html: This will make the filename.txt opened for reading.

content.text: It requires a little bit of work to read a file in C. Hang in there! We will guide you step-by-step.
content.html: It requires a little bit of work to read a file in C. Hang in there! We will guide you step-by-step.

content.text: Next, we need to create a string that should be big enough to store the content of the file.
content.html: Next, we need to create a string that should be big enough to store the content of the file.

content.text: For example, let's create a string that can store up to 100 characters:
content.html: For example, let's create a string that can store up to 100 characters:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
FILE *fptr;// Open a file in read modefptr = fopen("filename.txt", "r");
    // Store the content of the filechar myString[100];
// Open a file in read mode
// Store the content of the file

content.code:
FILE *fptr;// Open a file in read modefptr = fopen("filename.txt", "r");
// Store the content of the filechar myString[100];

syntax_highlighting.text:
FILE *fptr;// Open a file in read modefptr = fopen("filename.txt", "r");
 // Store the content of the filechar myString[100];
// Open a file in read mode
// Store the content of the file

content.code_html:
FILE *fptr;

// Open a file in read mode
fptr = fopen("filename.txt", "r");

// Store the content of the file
char myString[100];

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
FILE *fptr;// Open a file in read modefptr = fopen("filename.txt", "r");
    // Store the content of the filechar myString[100];
// Open a file in read mode
// Store the content of the file

content.text: In order to read the content of filename.txt , we can use the fgets() function.
content.html: In order to read the content of filename.txt, we can use the fgets() function.

content.text: The fgets() function takes three parameters:

content.code_html: fgets(myString, 100, fptr);

content.text: Now, we can print the string, which will output the content of the file:
content.html: Now, we can print the string, which will output the content of the file:

syntaxHighlighting.text: // Open a file in read mode
// Store the content of the file

// Read 
    the content and store it inside myString

syntax_highlighting.text: // Open a file in read mode
// Store the content of the file

// Read 
    the content and store it inside myString

content.code_html:
FILE *fptr;

// Open a file in read mode
fptr = fopen("filename.txt", "r");

// Store the content of the file
char myString[100];

// Read the content and store it inside myString
fgets(myString, 100, fptr);

// Print the file content
printf("%s", myString);

// Close the file
fclose(fptr);

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // Open a file in read mode
// Store the content of the file

// Read 
    the content and store it inside myString

content.text: Note: The fgets function only reads the first line of the file. If you remember, there were two lines of text in filename.txt .
content.html: Note: The fgets function only reads the first line of the file. If you remember, there were two lines of text in filename.txt.

content.text: To read every line of the file, you can use a while loop:
content.html: To read every line of the file, you can use a while loop:

syntaxHighlighting.text: // Open a file in read mode
// Store the content of the file
// Read the content and print it

syntax_highlighting.text: // Open a file in read mode
// Store the content of the file
// Read the content and print it

content.code_html:
FILE *fptr;

// Open a file in read mode
fptr = fopen("filename.txt", "r");

// Store the content of the file
char myString[100];

// Read the content and print it
 while(fgets(myString, 100, fptr)) {
  printf("%s", myString);
}

// Close the file
fclose(fptr);

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // Open a file in read mode
// Store the content of the file
// Read the content and print it

content.text: If you try to open a file for reading that does not exist, the fopen() function will return NULL .
content.html: If you try to open a file for reading that does not exist, the fopen() function will return NULL.

content.text: Tip: As a good practice, we can use an if statement to test for NULL , and print some text instead (when the file does not exist):
content.html: Tip: As a good practice, we can use an if statement to test for NULL, and print some text instead (when the file does not exist):

syntaxHighlighting.text:
FILE *fptr;// Open a file in read modefptr = 
    fopen("loremipsum.txt", "r");// Print some text 
    if the file does not existif(fptr == NULL) {  printf("Not able to open the 
    file.");}// Close the filefclose(fptr);
// Open a file in read mode

// Print some text 
    if the file does not exist

content.code:
FILE *fptr;// Open a file in read modefptr =
fopen("loremipsum.txt", "r");// Print some text
if the file does not existif(fptr == NULL) {  printf("Not able to open the
file.");}// Close the filefclose(fptr);

syntax_highlighting.text:
FILE *fptr;// Open a file in read modefptr = 
    fopen("loremipsum.txt", "r");// Print some text 
    if the file does not existif(fptr == NULL) {  printf("Not able to open the 
    file.");}// Close the filefclose(fptr);
// Open a file in read mode

// Print some text 
    if the file does not exist

content.code_html:
FILE *fptr;

// Open a file in read mode
fptr = fopen("loremipsum.txt", "r");

// Print some text if the file does not exist
if(fptr == NULL) {
  printf("Not able to open the file.");
}

// Close the file
fclose(fptr);

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
FILE *fptr;// Open a file in read modefptr = 
    fopen("loremipsum.txt", "r");// Print some text 
    if the file does not existif(fptr == NULL) {  printf("Not able to open the 
    file.");}// Close the filefclose(fptr);
// Open a file in read mode

// Print some text 
    if the file does not exist

content.text: With this in mind, we can create a more sustainable code if we use our "read a file" example above again:
content.html: With this in mind, we can create a more sustainable code if we use our "read a file" example above again:

syntaxHighlighting.text: // Open a file in read mode
// Store the content of the file
// Read the content and print it

// 
    If the file does not exist

syntax_highlighting.text: // Open a file in read mode
// Store the content of the file
// Read the content and print it

// 
    If the file does not exist

content.code_html:
FILE *fptr;

// Open a file in read mode
fptr = fopen("filename.txt", "r");

// Store the content of the file
char myString[100];

// If the file exist
if(fptr != NULL) {

  // Read the content and print it
  while(fgets(myString, 100, fptr)) {
    printf("%s", myString);
  }

// If the file does not exist
} else {
  printf("Not able to open the file.");
}

// Close the file
 fclose(fptr);

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // Open a file in read mode
// Store the content of the file
// Read the content and print it

// 
    If the file does not exist

content.text: Exercise ? What is this? Test your skills by answering a few questions about the topics of this page
Which mode should you use to open a file for reading in C?
content.html: Which mode should you use to open a file for reading in C?
